classFeature.name: Reliable Partner
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can outperform anyone if you take your time to do things well. If you spend at least 10 minutes performing a task, you gain a +5 bonus to the ability check you make for it.

Beginning at 15th level, your skills have improved considerably to the point you only need to spend at least 1 minute performing a task to gain the bonus. This bonus increases to +10 if you spend at least 10 minutes performing a task.

entries.name: Changes to Unarmed Strikes and the Finesse Property
entries: In this compendium unarmed strikes and the finesse property suffer important changes meant to keep balance in check.

entries.name: Finesse Property
entries: The property now allows to choose between your Strength or Dexterity modifier only for the attack roll with the weapon, but not for the damage roll. For the damage roll you still have to use your Strength modifier for melee weapon attacks or your Dexterity modifier for ranged weapon attacks.

entries.name: Unarmed Strikes
entries: Unarmed strikes are now considered to have the finesse and light properties.

classFeature.name: Roguish Talents
entries: Be it luck or a natural gift, you have a talent for succeeding in whatever you want. At 1st level, you have a pool of luck represented by a number of d6s, as shown in the Talent Pool column of the Rogue table. This pool is known as your Talent die.

entries.name: Talents
entries: A talent is an ability that allows you to spend your pool of d6s in particular ways. You begin having two {@filter talents|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:T} of your choice. Your {@filter talents|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:T} are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain rogue levels, you acquire additional talents of your choice, as shown in the Acquired Talents column of the Rogue table.

When you use a talent, you can spend a number of d6s from your pool equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) or less. Roll the spent die and add them to the die roll associated to your talent. You regain all of your expended die when you finish a short or long rest.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace a talent you have with another one.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics
entries: In order to survive in a harsh, competitive environment, you worked on your dirty tricks, known as {@filter Underhanded Tactics|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:UT}, each detailed below. The number of underhanded tactics you know is shown in the Known Tactics column of the Rogue table.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics improvement
entries: At 7th level, you learn an additional {@filter Underhanded Tactic|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:UT} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics improvement
entries: At 14th level, you learn an additional {@filter Underhanded Tactic|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:CS} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: At 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Use an Object} action as a bonus action.

classFeature.name: Cheaper Craft
entries: It's important to make do with what little you have. At 2nd level, you learn how to craft certain items using cheaper materials. When you are crafting either a nonmagical or consumable item, you can reduce its material cost by a percentage equal to 15 times your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 5 percent). However, by doing so you sacrifice the item's quality. Thus, any item you craft in this way lasts for 24 hours and sells for a quarter of its selling price. After that time, the item breaks or loses potency, and the materials can't be reclaimed.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation
entries: At 3rd level, you dedicate to a vocation that helps you compete in the market, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your archetype grants you features at 3rd level and again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 3rd level, choose two of your proficiencies, either in skills or with tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 10th level, you can choose two more of your skill or tool proficiencies to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 10th level, you can choose two more of your skill or tool proficiencies to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 20th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption
entries: At 5th level, your fast hands can quickly activate certain magical items. You can use your Cunning Action to use a consumable magic item as a bonus action, such as potions or spell scrolls. The rarity of the item can't be greater than uncommon. You can use rare items with this feature at 11th level, and very rare ones at 18th level.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption improvement
entries: At 11th level you can use rare items with this feature.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption improvement
entries: At 11th level you can use very rare items with this feature.

classFeature.name: Quick Learner
entries: Also at 5th level, you can prepare for any situation you might face in the short future. During a long rest, you can spend 1 hour learning how to use a skill or tool you have no proficiency with. At the end of the long rest, you add your proficiency bonus to checks using that skill or tool you studied. This benefit lasts until you use this feature again or you gain proficiency in the respective skill or tool.

entries.name: The Quick Learner Effect
entries: When imported via Plutonium, the feature will create an effect in you character sheet to add this benefit to a skill and a tool. By default it is set to add your proficiency bonus to your Acrobatics skill, and no bonus to your thieves' tools, you can manually modify it according to your choices.

classFeature.name: Shared Misfortune
entries: Bad luck always strikes at the worst possible time, unless it happens to someone else. At 7th level, whenever a creature that you can see within 30 feet from you makes an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can give the creature disadvantage on the roll. When you do so, you can't use this feature again before the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Opportunity for Improvement
entries: No matter how dire the situation is, you can always count on your talent to fix it. Starting at 14th level, when you roll for initiative and have no Talent die remaining, you regain two Talent die. You also regain one Talent die when you fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw on your turn.

classFeature.name: Mastery
entries: At 19th level, choose two of your proficiencies, either in skills or with tools. Your proficiency bonus is tripled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

entries.name: The Mastery Effect
entries: When imported via Plutonium, the feature will create an effect in you character sheet to add this benefit to a skill and a tool. By default it is set to add double your proficiency bonus to your Acrobatics skill and your thieves' tools, you can manually modify it according to your choices.

{@i {@b Skills' Abbreviations.}} The following is a list with all the skill's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the skill it corresponds to: acr (Acrobatics), ani (Animal Handling), arc (Acrobatics), ath (Athletics), dec (Deception), his (History), ins (Insight), itm (Intimidation), inv (Investigation), med (Medicine), nat (Nature), prc (Perception), prf (Performance), per (Persuasion), rel (Religion), slt (Sleight of Hands), ste (Stealth), sur (Survival).

{@i {@b Tools' Abbreviations.}} The following is a list with all the tool's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the tool it corresponds to: art (artisan's tools), alchemist, brewer, calligrapher, carpenter, cartographer, coobler, cook, glassblower, jeweler, leatherworker, mason, painter, potter, smith, tinker, weaver, woodcarver, disg (disguise kit), forg (forgery kit), game (gaming set), chess (chess set), dice (dice set), card (playing cards set), herb (herbalism kit), music (musical instrument), bagpipes, drum, dulcimer, flute, horn, lute, lyre, panflute, shawm, viol, navg (navigator's tools), pois (poisoner's kit), thief (thieves' tools), vehicle (vehicles), air (air vehicle), land (vehicle), space (space vehicle), water (water vehicle)

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. Before you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.
You can use this feature three times, you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
In addition, when you finish a long rest, you can choose one of your acquired talents and replace it with a different one.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: Before you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw

optionalfeature.name: Swift Hands
entries: You can take an additional object interaction, which you can use exclusively to draw, seathe, or store a weapon.

optionalfeature.name: Crushing Blow
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage, you can impose a Strength saving throw on the target. The save DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier. On a failed save, the creature is knocked {@condition prone}.
You can use this technique a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses after you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage

optionalfeature.name: Poker
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon that deals piercing damage, you can impose that creature to have disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of their next turn.
You can use this technique a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses after you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals piercing damage

optionalfeature.name: Bleeding
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals slashing damage, you can cause the creature to bleed until the start of its next turn, where it takes slashing damage equal to one roll of your Technical Dice. The next healing the creature receives stops the bleeding, but regains no hit points from it. This technique has no effect on constructs and undeads.
You can use this technique a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses after you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals slashing damage

optionalfeature.name: Changing Weapons
entries: You learn the {@optfeature Swift Hands|DZC:ANA:Ro} technique.

optionalfeature.name: Bludgeoning Weapons
entries: You learn the {@optfeature Crushing Blow|DZC:ANA:Ro} technique.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage

optionalfeature.name: Piercing Weapons
entries: You learn the {@optfeature Poker|DZC:ANA:Ro} technique.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals piercing damage

optionalfeature.name: Slashing Weapons
entries: You learn the {@optfeature Bleeding|DZC:ANA:Ro} technique.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack that deals slashing damage

optionalfeature.name: Shield
entries: You can equip a shield the moment you roll initiative (no action required) at the cost of a -3 penalty to your initiative roll.

optionalfeature.name: Light Armor
entries: If you were to be hit by a critical attack, or were to take damage that would reduce you to 0 hit points, you can choose to destroy the light armor you're wearing, reducing that instance of damage to 0.

optionalfeature.name: Medium Armor
entries: You increase by 1 the maximum Dexterity modifier you can add to your AC while wearing medium armor.

optionalfeature.name: Heavy Armor
entries: While wearing heavy armor, the bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage that you take is reduced by 3.

optionalfeature.name: Durability
entries: At the start of your turn, if you have less than your maximum hit points, you can take a deep breath to regain your strength. When you do so, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 1d10 + your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1).
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: At the start of your turn, if you have less than your maximum hit points

optionalfeature.name: Perseverance
entries: With enough time, you can carve a path through the mightiest mountain. Standing up from {@condition prone} only costs you 10 feet of movement.

optionalfeature.name: Stamina
entries: You can momentarily ignore the fatigue of your body. When you roll initiative, if you have the {@condition exhaustion} condition, you can choose to reduce its level by one for the duration of the combat, or until you are knocked unconscious.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Unyielding
entries: If you start your turn at 0 hit points, you can choose to regain 1 hit point at the cost of one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

optionalfeature.name: Ambush
entries: When you make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check or an initiative roll, you can expend one superiority die and add the die to the roll, provided you aren't {@condition incapacitated}.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Dexterity (Stealth) check or an initiative roll

optionalfeature.name: Bait and Switch
entries: When you're within 5 feet of a creature on your turn, you can expend one superiority die and switch places with that creature, provided you spend at least 5 feet of movement and the creature is willing and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.
Roll the superiority die. Until the start of your next turn, you or the other creature (your choice) gains a bonus to AC equal to the number rolled.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you're within 5 feet of a creature on your turn

optionalfeature.name: Brace
entries: When a creature you can see moves into the reach you have with the melee weapon you're wielding, you can use your reaction to expend one superiority die and make one attack against the creature, using that weapon. If the attack hits, add the superiority die to the weapon's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature you can see moves into your reach

optionalfeature.name: Commanding Presence
entries: When you make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}), a Charisma ({@skill Performance}), or a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, you can expend one superiority die and add the superiority die to the ability check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Charisma (Intimidation), a Charisma (Performance), or a Charisma (Persuasion) check

optionalfeature.name: Commander's Strike
entries: When you take the Attack action on your turn, you can forgo one of your attacks and use a bonus action to direct one of your companions to strike. When you do so, choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you and expend one superiority die. That creature can immediately use its reaction to make one weapon attack, adding the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you take the Attack action on your turn and forgo one attack

optionalfeature.name: Disarming Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to disarm the target, forcing it to drop one item of your choice that it's holding. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it drops the object you choose. The object lands at its feet.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Distracting Strike
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to distract the creature, giving your allies an opening. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll. The next attack roll against the target by an attacker other than you has advantage if the attack is made before the start of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Evasive Footwork
entries: When you move, you can expend one superiority die, rolling the die and adding the number rolled to your AC until you stop moving.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you move

optionalfeature.name: Feinting Attack
entries: You can expend one superiority die and use a bonus action on your turn to feint, choosing one creature within 5 feet of you as your target. You have advantage on your next attack roll against that creature this turn. If that attack hits, add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

optionalfeature.name: Goading Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to goad the target into attacking you. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target has disadvantage on all attack rolls against targets other than you until the end of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Grappling Attack
entries: Immediately after you hit a creature with a melee attack on your turn, you can expend one superiority die and then try to grapple the target as a bonus action. Add the superiority die to your Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: Immediately after you hit a creature with a melee attack on your turn

optionalfeature.name: Lunging Attack
entries: When you make a melee weapon attack on your turn, you can expend one superiority die to increase your reach for that attack by 5 feet. If you hit, you add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Maneuvering Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to maneuver one of your comrades into a more advantageous position. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and you choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you. That creature can use its reaction to move up to half its speed without provoking opportunity attacks from the target of your attack.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Menacing Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to frighten the target. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Indomitable
entries: When you fail a saving throw, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to add it to the roll, potentially causing the save to succeed.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you fail a saving throw

optionalfeature.name: Parry
entries: When another creature damages you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to reduce the damage by the number you roll on your superiority die + your Dexterity modifier.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When another creature damages you with a melee attack

optionalfeature.name: Precision Attack
entries: When you make a weapon attack roll against a creature, you can expend one superiority die to add it to the roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a weapon attack roll against a creature

optionalfeature.name: Pushing Attack
entries: When you hit with a weapon attack a creature no more than one size larger than you, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to drive the target back. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and if the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you push the target up to 10 feet away from you.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Quick Toss
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend one superiority die and make a ranged attack with a weapon that has the thrown property. You can draw the weapon as part of making this attack. If you hit, add the superiority die to the weapon's damage roll.

optionalfeature.name: Rally
entries: On your turn, you can use a bonus action and expend one superiority die to bolster the resolve of one of your companions. When you do so, choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you. That creature gains temporary hit points equal to the superiority die roll + your Charisma modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Riposte
entries: When a creature misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to make a melee weapon attack against the creature. If you hit, you add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature misses you with a melee attack

optionalfeature.name: Slowing Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to reduce that creature's speed. Roll your superiority die. The creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or have its speed reduced an ammount in feet equal to 5 times the number rolled on your superiority die. This effect lasts until the start of your next turn. If the maneuver reduces a creature's speed to 0, it becomes {@condition restrained} for the duration.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Sweeping Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to damage another creature with the same attack. Choose another creature within 5 feet of the original target and within your reach. If the original attack roll would hit the second creature, it takes damage equal to the number you roll on your superiority die. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Tactical Assessment
entries: When you make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}), an Intelligence ({@skill History}), or a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, you can expend one superiority die and add the superiority die to the ability check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make an Intelligence (Investigation), an Intelligence (History), or a Wisdom (Insight) check

optionalfeature.name: Trip Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to knock the target down. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and if the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target {@condition prone}.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Abjuration
entries: A creature can't be disarmed of this weapon against its will.

optionalfeature.name: Conjuration
entries: You can summon your bonded weapons to your hands as a bonus action, causing it to teleport instantly to your hand.

optionalfeature.name: Divination
entries: When you roll a 1 on an attack roll using your bonded weapons, you can reroll the die. You must use the new result.

optionalfeature.name: Enchantment
entries: If you hit a creature with your bonded weapons, it has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} by a spell you cast before the end of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Evocation
entries: When you make an attack with your bonded weapon, you can change its damage type to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder.

optionalfeature.name: Illusion
entries: The first time you attack with each of your bonded weapons on each of your turns, you create a mirage of your attack that gives you advantage on the attack roll. A creature is unaffected by this feature if it cant see, if it relies on senses other than sight, or if it can perceive illusions as false.

optionalfeature.name: Necromancy
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with an attack made with your bonded weapons, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with an attack made with your bonded weapons

optionalfeature.name: Transmutation
entries: As a bonus action, you can turn your light bonded weapons into heavy weapons, and viceversa. Alternatively, you can add or remove the property into your bonded weapons if it didn't have it initially.

subclassFeature.name: Champion
entries: A champion is the first thing that comes to mind when anyone thinks of a fighter, a hero who has defeated great foes by overwhelming them with their physical superiority. These fighters lack any special ability, so they train nonstop to bring their bodies to reach limits beyond what is humanly possible.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your weapon attacks also score a critical hit on a roll of 19. They also score a critical hit on a roll of 18 at 7th level, 17 at 15th, and 16 at 18th.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Starting at 7th level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 18-20.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Starting at 15th level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 17-20.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Starting at 18th level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 16-20.

subclassFeature.name: Physical Expertise
entries: Also at 3rd level, your dedicated physical training bears fruit. You gain proficiency in Acrobatics and Athletics if you don't already have them. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses these skills.
In addition, your jumping distance increases by a number of feet equal to five times your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Remarkable Athlete
entries: At 7th level, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) to any Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution check you make that doesn't already use your proficiency bonus.
In addition, climbing and swimming doesn't cost you extra movement.

subclassFeature.name: Diamond Body
entries: At 15th level, your body can whitstand terrible attacks. When a creature scores a critical hit against you, you can use your reaction to turn it into a normal hit.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature scores a critical hit against you

subclassFeature.name: Survivor
entries: At 18th level, you attain the pinnacle of resilience in battle. At the start of each of your turns, you regain hit points equal to 5 + your Constitution modifier if you have no more than half of your hit points left. You don't gain this benefit if you have 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Knight
entries: Some fighters incorporate magic into their studies, becoming arcane knights. Thus they enlist to wizard academies or take a wizard as an instructor. An arcane knight studies magic to expand their repertoir of abilities in order to increase both their adaptability and versatility. However, given the secondary the priority of their magical studies are, they opt for an intensive rather than extensive approach. Hence why they only pick a few schools of magic to learn and then memorize a few spells from these.

subclassFeature.name: Schools of Magic
entries: When you choose this tradition you must choose the two schools of magic that your character will study. The schools are {@filter Abjuration|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=a}, {@filter Conjuration|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=c}, {@filter Divination|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=d}, {@filter Enchantment|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=e}, {@filter Evocation|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=v}, {@filter Illusion|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=i}, {@filter Necromancy|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=n}, and {@filter Transmutation|spells|subclass=Fighter: Eldritch Knight|school=t}. Whenever a feature in this subclass refers to your schools of magic, it refers to the ones you chose.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you augment your martial prowess with the ability to cast spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn three cantrips of your choice from your schools of magic on the wizard spell list. You learn an additional cantrip of your choice with the same restrictions at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Arcane Knight Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spells Known
entries: You know a number of wizard spells of your choice that are available for you to cast. The spells you choose must be from your schools of magic on the wizard spell list. The number of wizard spells you know is equal to your Intelligence modifier + a third of your fighter level (minimum of one spell).
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another one of your choice with the same restrictions.

entries.name: Spells Known
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your spells through study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Weapon Bond
entries: At 3rd level, you learn a ritual that creates a magical bond between yourself and one weapon. You perform the ritual over the course of 1 hour, which can be done during a short rest. The weapon must be within your reach throughout the ritual, at the conclusion of which you touch the weapon and forge the bond.

Once you have bonded a weapon to yourself, it counts as an arcane focus to you and it gains special properties depending on your schools of magic, each described below, as long as it is on the same plane of existence as you. These properties end if your weapon is no longer bonded to you or if you are unconscious.
You can have up to two bonded weapons. If you attempt to bond with a third weapon, you must break the bond with one of the other two.

subclassFeature.name: War Magic
entries: Beginning at 7th level, when you use your action to cast a cantrip, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action. At 18th level, you can make this special attack when you use your action to cast any spell.

subclassFeature.name: War Magic improvement
entries: At 18th level, you can make this special attack when you use your action to cast any spell.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Charge
entries: At 15th level, you learn how to store residual magic inside of you, known as Arcane Charge. If you hit a creature with a weapon attack you can spend your Arcane Charge for one of the following effects:

items: The creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against a spell before the end of your next turn.
You can teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see, gaining advantage on your next weapon attack before the end your turn.

entries.name: Fighter
entries: A stunning half-orc completely covered in metal armor stands tall next to her partners, rising her shield to protect them. Positioning herself in front of them, she prevents the ice mephits from freezing her allies by absorbing the most damage she can. She hopes that with this act of sacrifice she achieves the recognition of the knights order and win the grace of a noble family.

At first glance he looks nothing much other than a plain thug, the drow sits at the bar, glancing over the people gathered in the stablishment, finding the meanest looking mercenaries, observing their every move. When they take notice they decide they don't like the fella spying on them, so it's time to take it outside. What they failed to realize was that the elf was studying their every weakness, which would bring forth their demise.

An expreinced general directs the actions of his squad during a battle, maneuvering their positioning, coordinating their attacks, and protecting from most danger, so that they can be as efficient as possible. He was chosen not for his skills in combat, but for being an expert in the field of leadership, tactical genius, and succeeding in wars that seemed impossible to win.

All of these epic warriors are fighters, one of the most versatile combatants in the world. Since they lack any super natural powers, they cultivate their martial talents in order to surpass mortal limits, to the point they are known for their high competence in any field of combat, wether it's about wielding a weapon for destructive purposses or by learning the weak points of an enemy.

entries.name: Well-Rounded Specialist
entries: Fighters learn the basics of all combat styles. Every fighter can swing an axe, fence with a rapier, wield a longsword or a greatsword, use a bow, and even trap foes in a net with some degree of skill. Likewise, a fighter is adept with shields and every form of armor. Beyond that basic degree of familiarity, each fighter specializes in a certain style of combat, defined by the path they took to become one. Some concentrate on archery, some on ambushing unsuspecting victims, and some on augmenting their martial skills with magic. This combination of broad general ability and extensive specialization makes fighters superior combatants on battlefields and in dungeons alike.

entries.name: Trained for Danger
entries: Not every member of the city watch, the village militia, or the queen's army is a fighter. Most of these troops are relatively untrained soldiers with only the most basic combat knowledge. Veteran soldiers, military officers, trained bodyguards, dedicated knights, and similar figures are fighters. However, anyone with the right set of skills and mindset can develop their talents to become a fighter.

Some fighters feel drawn to use their training as adventurers. The dungeon delving, monster slaying, and other dangerous work common among adventurers is second nature for a fighter, not all that different from the life they left behind. There are greater risks, perhaps, but also much greater rewardsfew fighters in the city watch have the opportunity to discover a magic flame tongue sword, for example.

entries.name: Creating a Fighter
entries: As you build your fighter, think about two related elements of your character's background: Where did you get your combat training, and what set you apart from the mundane warriors around you? Were you particularly ruthless? Did you get extra help from a mentor, perhaps because of your exceptional dedication? What drove you to this training in the first place? A threat to your homeland, a thirst for revenge, or a need to prove yourself might all have been factors.

You might have enjoyed formal training in a noble's army or in a local militia. Perhaps you trained in a war academy, learning strategy, tactics, and military history. Or you might be self-taughtunpolished but well tested. Did you take up the sword as a way to escape the limits of life on a farm, or are you following a proud family tradition? Where did you acquire your weapons and armor? They might have been military issue or family heirlooms, or perhaps you scrimped and saved for years to buy them. Your armaments are now among your most important possessionsthe only things that stand between you and death's embrace.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a fighter quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Strength or Dexterity your highest ability score, depending on whether you want to focus on melee or ranged weapons. Your next highest score should be Constitution, or Intelligence if you plan to adopt a magical subclass. Second, choose the {@background soldier} background.

entries.name: Can I add this Bonus?
entries: Sometimes an ability, feature, or spell allows you to add a bonus to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, such as the bard's Bardic Inspiration, a war cleric's  Channel Divinity: Guided Strike, the *bless* spell, the martial technique boost offensive, and many others. Other abilities allow you to reroll the die for those die rolls, such as the drunken master monk's Drunkard's Luck. There is another type of abilities, much rarer than the others, ones that allow you to add special effects to your actions, reactions, die rolls, etc., such as the monk's Evasion ki feature. These abilities have in common the lack of key words for its trigger, such as hit, succeed, miss, or fail, which is why you can choose to use these after seeing the roll, but before the DM says wether the roll succeeds or fails.
